items.title: OpenAI’s new ChatGPT image generator makes faking photos easy
Browser extensions with 8 million users collect extended AI conversations
Merriam-Webster’s word of the year delivers a dismissive verdict on junk AI content
Microsoft will finally kill obsolete cipher that has wreaked decades of havoc
Roomba maker iRobot swept into bankruptcy
OpenAI built an AI coding agent and uses it to improve the agent itself
items.summary:
- OpenAI treats Codex as a valuable coding tool with rapid gains and alignment to empowering developers, while maintaining humans in the loop.
- They emphasize Codex as an amplifier of human potential, address job-displacement concerns, and aim to extend coding agents to non-programmers in the future.
- The team is building a coding agent for engineers now but seeks a more general agent for broader users, with METR study noted in the 2025 update.

items.title: OpenAI releases GPT-5.2 after “code red” Google threat alert
items.summary:
- GPT-5.2 arrives in Instant/Thinking/Pro, with 400k context and Aug 31, 2025 cutoff; GPT-5.1 stays as a 3-month legacy; API at $1.75 per million input tokens. 
- Instant=fast writing/translation; Thinking=more complex simulated reasoning (coding/math); Pro=highest accuracy and reasoning; improvements across spreadsheets, coding, image perception, and long-context use. 
- Code red after Google Gemini 3 topped benchmarks; Gemini 3 >650M MAU, ChatGPT ~800M WAU; OpenAI pledges ~$1.4T for AI infra.

items.title: Disney invests $1 billion in OpenAI, licenses 200 characters for AI video app Sora
items.summary:
- Disney commits $1B to expand OpenAI partnership for Sora 2, enabling short videos built from Disney IP (Mickey, Frozen, Toy Story) with costumes, props, vehicles, and environments.
- OpenAI will allow Disney-sanctioned content through moderation; ChatGPT image generator gains official IP access; a curated set of fan-made Sora videos will stream on Disney+ from early 2026.
- No talent likenesses or voices; the deal emphasizes responsible collaboration with robust controls and signals a shift in Disney's stance and long-term IP/AI entertainment implications.

items.title: Oracle shares slide on $15B increase in data center spending
items.summary:
- Oracle’s cloud infra revenue was $4.1B; net income rose to $6.1B aided by a $2.7B pre-tax gain from selling Ampere to SoftBank.
- The company added 400 MW of data-center capacity and is building a large Abilene, TX cluster for OpenAI, with demand from other customers if OpenAI does not fully fill its contracted capacity.
- Oracle funds growth with debt—sold $18B of bonds in September and seeking about $38B more; it leases data-center capacity and aims to preserve investment-grade ratings.

items.title: A new open-weights AI coding model is closing in on proprietary options
items.summary: - Mistral AI released Devstral 2 (123B) open-weights coding model for autonomous software engineering, with 72.2% on SWE-bench Verified; Devstral Small 2 (24B) scores 68% and runs offline; both support 256k-token context.\n- Mistral Vibe CLI enables terminal interaction, project scanning, cross-file changes, and shell automation under open licenses (Devstral 2: modified MIT, Small 2: Apache 2.0).\n- SWE-bench Verified is a standardized but imperfect metric; many tasks are simple bug fixes that experienced engineers can complete quickly.

items.title: Operation Bluebird wants to relaunch “Twitter,” says Musk abandoned the name and logo
items.summary:
- Operation Bluebird, led by a Chicago IP firm, seeks to reclaim the Twitter name and bird logo for a relaunch focused on branding services.
- Advertisers remain wary of associating with X amid concerns about extremist content, scams, and bots, while Threads gains ground.
- Trademark experts warn X must show actual use or intent to resume use to defend the marks; branding fade could trigger abandonment risk.

items.title: Meta offers EU users ad-light option in push to end investigation
items.summary:
- Meta says personalized ads are vital for Europe’s economy as the DMA probe continues.
- The EU’s DMA inquiries also target Google, Amazon, and Microsoft, and Brussels has opened a separate antitrust probe into Meta over AI providers’ access to WhatsApp.
- The EU recently fined X 120 million euros for digital-transparency breaches, drawing US criticisms of regulatory overreach.

items.title: In comedy of errors, men accused of wiping gov databases turned to an AI tool
items.summary: - Two former federal contractors, Muneeb and Sohaib Akhter, were charged after attempting to access employer and government databases minutes after being fired.\n- They allegedly consulted an AI chat tool to learn how to clear SQL server logs and Windows Event logs to cover their tracks.\n- The case centers on the deletion of 96 databases containing sensitive files and the subsequent wipe of employer laptops.

items.title: Admins and defenders gird themselves against maximum-severity server vuln
Microsoft drops AI sales targets in half after salespeople miss their quotas
items.summary:
- Microsoft slashed AI-agent sales targets after reps missed quotas, signaling slower enterprise uptake of multi-step agents like Foundry and Copilot Studio.
- Quotas cuts reflect concerns about AI agents' brittleness and confabulation, and questions about paying a premium for autonomous tools.
- Microsoft remains heavy on AI infrastructure spending while most AI revenue comes from firms renting cloud infra, delaying broad enterprise adoption.

items.title: Fraudulent gambling network may actually be something more nefarious
OpenAI CEO declares “code red” as Gemini gains 200 million users in 3 months
items.summary:
- Gemini hits 650M MAU in October; ChatGPT surpasses 800M weekly users.
- OpenAI declares 'code red' amid competitive pressure; profitability still uncertain.
- Thrive Capital stake and Accenture collaboration; new simulated reasoning model allegedly beating Gemini 3 in internal tests.

items.title: Syntax hacking: Researchers discover sentence structure can bypass AI safety rules
items.summary:
- Syntax patterns can trump semantics, causing cross-domain accuracy drops when domain templates are used.
- A syntax-hacking vulnerability can bypass safety filters; chain-of-thought prompts escalate risk.
- Limitations include data-source uncertainties and memorization effects, with implications for cross-domain safety.

items.title: HP plans to save millions by laying off thousands, ramping up AI use
items.summary:
- HP will cut 4,000–6,000 jobs by fiscal 2028 to fund AI deployments, aiming for about $1B in annualized savings, mainly in product development, operations, and support.
- This aligns with a broader AI-driven layoff trend (Salesforce, Amazon, Intuit, Klarna, Duolingo, Meta) as firms push AI.
- HP says AI will speed innovation, improve customer satisfaction, and boost productivity as part of digital transformation and portfolio optimization.

items.title: Crypto hoarders dump tokens as shares tumble
items.summary:
- Wintermute says corporate crypto treasuries are too big; many are selling to fund buybacks, reversing the crypto-treasury model.
- FG Nexus, ETHZilla and Sequans sold ether/bitcoin (Sequans about $100M) to service debt or bolster balance sheets; Strategy doubles down on bitcoin.
- Morgan McCarthy warns 95% of treasuries could go to zero; Michael Saylor calls volatility 'Satoshi's gift'.
